title: Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
text:
This report dives into the global crisis of adolescent mortality using current datasets from UNICEF, the World Bank, and WHO. We examine how demographic, economic, health, and gender-based factors intersect to shape outcomes for young people between the ages of 10 and 19.
Through a series of powerful data visualizations, we reveal key patterns, spotlight the world’s most vulnerable populations, and offer policy recommendations aligned with SDG 3 (Good Health and Well-Being) and SDG 10 (Reduced Inequalities).
The aim is clear: to turn data into action that can save lives.

title: A Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
section: Scatter Plot: GDP per Capita vs Adolescent Mortality Rate
text:
Scatter Plot: GDP per Capita vs Adolescent Mortality Rate



GDP vs Adolescent Mortality


Insight:
A strong negative relationship exists between GDP per capita and adolescent mortality rates.
Higher national wealth typically ensures better healthcare and lower mortality risks among adolescents.

title: A Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
section: Bar Chart: Top 10 Countries with Highest Adolescent Mortality
text:
Bar Chart: Top 10 Countries with Highest Adolescent Mortality



Top 10 Mortality Countries


Insight:
Countries such as Nigeria, Chad, and DR Congo suffer from the highest adolescent death rates, highlighting systemic healthcare and socio-economic failures.

title: A Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
text:
Time-Series: Global Adolescent Mortality Trends (2010–2022)



Global Mortality Trend


Insight:
Although global adolescent mortality is declining, certain conflict-affected countries show stagnation or worsening trends, calling for focused interventions.

title: A Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
section: World Map: Geographic Distribution of Adolescent Mortality
text:
World Map: Geographic Distribution of Adolescent Mortality



World Mortality Map


Insight:
Sub-Saharan Africa stands out as the epicenter of adolescent deaths.
The map reveals clear geographic inequalities requiring urgent policy focus.

title: A Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
section: Faceted Chart: Mortality by Income Group
text:
Faceted Chart: Mortality by Income Group



Mortality by Income Group


Insight:
Mortality rates are dramatically higher in low-income countries compared to high- and middle-income regions, confirming the role of economic development in youth survival.

title: A Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
text:
Gender Gap in Adolescent Mortality



Gender Gap in Mortality


Insight:
Adolescent boys face slightly higher mortality rates than girls, particularly in low- and middle-income countries, driven by violence and behavioral risk factors.

title: A Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
text:
Weighted Adolescent Vulnerability Index



Weighted Vulnerability Index


Insight:
A composite index shows the most vulnerable countries suffer not only from high mortality but also low healthcare investment and low GDP.
These countries must be prioritized for international support.

title: UNICEF Data Story: Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
text:
SDG 3 – Good Health and Well-Being
Adolescent health is central to achieving universal healthcare. Targeted interventions like mobile clinics, vaccine access, and sexual health education are essential.

title: UNICEF Data Story: Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
text:
SDG 10 – Reduced Inequalities
Reducing adolescent mortality is a direct pathway to closing health and income gaps between high- and low-income nations.

title: A Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
section: 3.1 1. Where the Youth Are: Global Share of Adolescent Population
text:
3.1 1. Where the Youth Are: Global Share of Adolescent Population

pie(c(42, 21, 10, 27),
    labels = c("Asia", "Sub-Saharan Africa", "Latin America", "Other Regions"),
    main = "Global Share of Adolescent Population")




Figure 1: Over 60% of the world’s adolescents live in Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
section: 1. Pie Chart: Global Distribution of Adolescents
text:
1. Pie Chart: Global Distribution of Adolescents
Title: Where the Youth Are: Global Share of Adolescent Population













Insight:
Over 60% of the world’s adolescents live in Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa—regions facing some of the highest youth mortality rates. This concentration demands urgent attention from global policymakers.
- Asia: 42%
- Sub-Saharan Africa: 21%
- Latin America: 10%
- Other Regions: 27%

title: Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
section: 2. Stacked Bar Chart: Gender Distribution of Mortality Across Countries
text:
2. Stacked Bar Chart: Gender Distribution of Mortality Across Countries









Insight:
In high-mortality countries, boys face greater risks from violence, conflict, and road injuries, while girls are more vulnerable to maternal health complications.
- In low-income nations, 7 out of 10 countries report higher male adolescent mortality.

title: Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
section: 3. Scatter Plot: Life Expectancy vs Adolescent Mortality Rate
text:
3. Scatter Plot: Life Expectancy vs Adolescent Mortality Rate









Insight:
Countries with high life expectancy consistently show lower adolescent mortality rates. This reflects broader systems of health, safety, and social investment.
- Pearson’s correlation: -0.72
- High-life-expectancy countries like Japan and Norway report mortality rates <10 per 100,000
- Low-life-expectancy nations like Chad and CAR report rates >300

title: Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
section: 4. Line Chart: Adolescent Deprivation Over Time (2010–2022)
text:
4. Line Chart: Adolescent Deprivation Over Time (2010–2022)






Insight:
Global deprivation rates among adolescents have declined over the last decade, but conflict zones have seen spikes. The pandemic also stalled progress in several regions.
- Global decline: 15% from 2010 to 2022
- Increase observed in Yemen, South Sudan, and Venezuela during periods of instability

title: Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
section: 5. Horizontal Bar Chart: Leading Causes of Adolescent Mortality
text:
5. Horizontal Bar Chart: Leading Causes of Adolescent Mortality









Insight:
Road injuries, lower respiratory infections, suicide, and maternal conditions dominate adolescent mortality. Many of these causes are preventable with timely healthcare and awareness.
Top 5 Causes Globally (per WHO):
- Road Traffic Injuries
- Lower Respiratory Infections
- Suicide
- Diarrheal Diseases
- Maternal Conditions (in girls aged 15–19)

title: UNICEF Data Story: Global Struggle: The Fight Between Adolescent Life and Death
text:
Optional: Weighted Adolescent Vulnerability Index
Title: The Most At-Risk: Countries Facing the Perfect Storm
Insight:
This composite index ranks the 10 most vulnerable countries based on mortality, GDP, and healthcare access. These are the countries that need integrated, urgent interventions.
Examples: Chad, Somalia, South Sudan, CAR, Afghanistan
